qas.question: Who owns the majority of critical habitat?

answers.text: non-federal property, owned by citizens, states, local governments, tribal governments and private organizations

qas.question: What program gives incentives to private landowners to protect species on their land?
Before the amendment in 1982, under what situations could a listed species be displaced?

answers.text: only for scientific or research purposes

qas.question: What fraction of habitat for listed species is owned by citizens?
When was it decided species could be taken for scientific purposes?
What purpose does the HCP state listed species cannot be taken for?
What can economic development not do under HCP?

context: <b3_0>More than half<b3_0/> of habitat for listed species is on <a0_0>non-federal property, owned by citizens, states, local governments, tribal governments and private organizations<a0_0/>. Before the law was amended in <b5_0>1982<b5_0/>, a listed species could be taken <a2_0>only for <b6_0>scientific or research purposes<b6_0/><a2_0/>. The amendment created a permit process to circumvent the take prohibition called a <a1_0><b4_0>Habitat Conservation Plan<a1_0/> or HCP<b4_0/> to give incentives to non-federal land managers and private landowners to help protect listed and unlisted species, while allowing economic development that may <b7_0>harm ("take") the species<b7_0/>.
